text:

Bel Air Middle School students this year raised $12,000 for The American Heart Association through Hoops for Heart, a long-standing tradition at the school. 
"It is truly a team effort on the part of many staff members who feel passionate about The American Heart Association and celebrating students' talents and efforts," seventh grade Language Arts teacher Amanda Ingram said. 
Faculty and a few other special friends helped celebrate the accomplishments with each grade level's own assembly Friday. 
Blair Thomas and Tyler Daniel from WXCY Radio in Havre de Grace were emcees for the event. The assemblies were packed with fun for everyone as students cheered from their bleacher seats and held up their signs for fellow student participants. Twenty students from each grade level grade competed in a two-round, three-point shooting contest. 
Between rounds, a team of students took on a team of their grade level teachers and special guests in a basketball game. Special guests included deputies from the Harford County Sheriff's Office, members of the boys and girls Bel Air High School basketball teams, and Officer Rick Krause from the Bel Air Police Department. 
Bel Air Middle School raised $12,000 for The American Heart Association through the Hoops for Heart event, a long standing tradition at the school. Faulty and staff held grade level assemblies on Friday to celebrte. (MATT BUTTON | AEGIS STAFF) 
The Aberdeen IronBirds donated 800 hats for the sixth- and seventh-grade students, as well as various giveaway prizes used by physical education teachers to celebrate the school's Hoops for Heart initiative accomplishments. Top fundraisers from each grade were honored during their respective assemblies and the top 30 fundraisers will enjoy a tour of Oriole Park at Camden Yards in the spring.
